Topic: Draw a habitat and the different living things in each
CAN: The student can draw basic land habitats such as playgrounds and gardens, recognizing that different environments exist.
The student can identify and attempt to draw a few types of water habitats, like ponds or streams, with mixed accuracy.
The student can illustrate and label a few common plants and animals, such as trees and squirrels, with some examples correctly placed in their respective habitats.
CANNOT: The student may not accurately draw more complex land habitats like forests or parking lots (student misunderstands the variety under 'land habitats').
The student might struggle to label or accurately depict diverse water habitats such as lakes (student mixes up water types).
The drawings may not clearly show patterns or comparisons between different habitats (student doesn't recognize patterns between habitats).
The student might not effectively demonstrate how certain plants and animals are specific to particular habitats (student attributes plants and animals to any environment).
The organization in their drawings might not effectively convey the diversity of life within a habitat (student lacks clear grouping or clustering of related elements).
